docs.lead_paragraph: Heather Ann Brownlee, the daughter of Eileen R. Brownlee of West Orange, N.J., and John S. Brownlee of Sparta, N.J., was married on Friday to Scott Lee Walker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Walker Jr. of Montville, N.J. The Rev. Ronald W. Johnson performed the ceremony at the Wyoming Presbyterian Church in Millburn, N.J. Mrs. Walker, 26, is a molecular biologist and neurobiologist at the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in Piscataway N.J. She was a member of a team at the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences that in 1994 contributed to the isolation and characterization of BRCA1, a gene whose presence may predispose a woman to breast or ovarian cancer. She graduated from North Carolina State University.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE voters lined up along Main Street here for the Memorial Day parade would have deflated county officials anywhere. When questioned about the Hunterdon County Board of Freeholders and the approaching primary race for three seats, Lewis Levi of Raritan Township gave an answer better informed than most: ''Freeholders,'' he said. ''They're like county council.'' Then, asked if he could name any freeholders, he said, with confidence, ''Absolutely not.'' All the same, Marcia Karrow, who was marching in the parade as Mayor of Raritan Township, wants to be a freeholder. So does her opponent, Georgene Brazer, who spent the day at home stuffing envelopes and working the phones. So do six other Hunterdon County Republicans who are running for two other seats.
docs.abstract: Article describes work of New Jersey freeholders, who are hard-working and low-paid equivalents of county commissioners or county supervisors in other states; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH trumpets and drum flourishes, the life insurance industry has rolled out a new organization intended to burnish its soiled reputation and convince Americans that it really is safe to do business with its agents. Most of the industry's leading companies have joined the group, called the Insurance Marketplace Standards Association. Members gain the right to include in their advertisements the organization's bull's-eye logo, which the group hopes will come to be regarded as a kind of Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval on policies.

headline.main: Will a New Association Give Insurers a Kinder Face?

docs.abstract: Life insurance industry, in bid to burnish soiled reputation, has formed Insurance Marketplace Standards Association; consumer advocates are skeptical that group will change way insurance agents operate or improve industry's image; group has no mechanism to discipline members; has rejected none of 170 companies that applied for membership (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN a winter storm destroyed the Albertson's store where Debra Chard used to work as a deli manager, she called it divine justice. She was relieved to get away from managers who, she said, pushed her to work before and after shifts and demanded that she work long hours with no breaks. ''They'd say, 'Don't expect to have a job if you don't get it done,' '' said Ms. Chard, of Bremerton, Wash., who has gone on to work for a different grocery store company. ''If I said 'I haven't punched in yet,' they'd say, 'Well, I'll fix that.' '' But, she said, they never did punch her in.

headline.main: When Overtime Doesn't Feel So Fine

docs.abstract: Overtime and uncompensated work have emerged as key labor issue in wake of staff cuts at many companies; increasingly robust job market is making employees feel secure enough to sue employers and and leave jobs they see as exploitive; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IF there is one national issue emerging from the hodgepodge of political campaigns that will take shape with primary elections in eight states on Tuesday, it is health insurance. Health maintenance organizations have taken over, and voters don't like it. So politicians are promising to do something about it. Candidates this fall for the Senate and House as well as governor and state attorney general are rallying behind legislation percolating in Congress and in state legislatures that promises to force H.M.O.'s to pay for more care, to expand patient choice and to require health plans to document how well they treat patients.

headline.main: Whiplash; In Health Care, Be Careful What You Wish For

docs.abstract: Health insurance has emerged as major election issue, with politicians rallying around proposed state and Federal bills that promise to force health maintenance organizations to pay for more care, expand patient choice and require health plans to document how well they treat patients; experts say such bills will backfire and restrict choice because of their elaborate record-keeping requirements; photo (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Even as a new Government-financed study raises questions about an increasingly popular way of paying for health services, many doctors and hospitals in New York City and a number of other big cities are embracing it. And while this form of managed care -- known as capitation -- gives health care providers more control, it also carries with it more financial risk. Some doctors love it, and some hate it. Few patients have heard of it. But after catching on in many parts of California and some other states, capitation is now rapidly rolling into networks of doctors and hospitals not only in New York City and the area around it -- notoriously one of the last places to adopt changes in health care delivery -- but also in places like Philadelphia, Boston and Atlanta.

headline.main: Risky Business; A Set Fee for Each Patient Gives Doctors More Control and More of a Financial Stake

docs.abstract: Many doctors and hospitals in New York City and number of other big cities are embracing form of managed care known as capitation, in which they get lump sum per enrollee; capitation gives care providers more control and carries more financial risk; gives doctors financial stake in holding down costs; new Government-financed study finds patients covered under such plans are less satisfied with care than people in health maintenance organizations whose doctors are paid for each service; table; graph; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Pakistan, Answering India, Conducts Nuclear Tests Pakistan responded to India's nuclear tests with underground nuclear tests of its own. Within hours, Pakistan's Prime Minister declared his country a ''nuclear power,'' fulfilling a secret plan made by a predecessor nearly 30 years ago that it would build an ''Islamic bomb.'' A1

docs.lead_paragraph: The United Healthcare Corporation, one of the nation's largest health insurers, agreed yesterday to buy Humana Inc. for $5.5 billion, further shrinking the number of competitors in the industry and narrowing the choices of managed-care plans for consumers. The combination of the health plans, with more than 10 million members across the country, would dominate the South Florida market. It would be the strongest insurer in Chicago and some other Midwestern cities.

headline.main: United Health To Acquire Humana Inc.
